stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on implementing a major visual rework of Course 1, provided by artist Biobak. The stream focused on fixing the resulting rendering and draw-order bugs, conducting performance tests, and importing a series of updated 3D models for various enemies and objects in the level. He also implemented a new dynamic sun flare effect requested by Biobak.

development_findings.summary: After implementing Biobak's graphical rework of Course 1, Kaze performed detailed performance benchmarks, noting the CPU is idle 73% of the time, and expects performance to improve further.
development_findings.quote: The CPU is not working two thirds of the time. I have someone making music for this, yes. And we don't even have the new actors here yet. So it's likely going to get even better.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented jiggle physics for Mario's nose using a custom, 'hyper-optimized' physics bone that calculates acceleration and applies pendulum physics, rather than using a standard animation.
development_findings.quote: It is a genuine physics bone I added to Mario... This is hyper-optimized. If you make one change to this, it's just gonna crash. But it works very well.

development_findings.summary: The team's workflow prioritizes finalizing visuals before updating the corresponding collision maps, which are currently out of sync with the reworked Course 1 geometry.
development_findings.quote: We reworked the level and some grounds changed. And the collision is not being worked with... We're finishing the visuals first and then collision.

development_findings.summary: Kaze expresses immense pride in the game's visual quality, stating he believes it's already the 'prettiest N64 game there is'.
development_findings.quote: I'm pretty sure this already is the prettiest N64 game there is. I don't think you can really make an argument against that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent significant time debugging N64-specific rendering order issues by manually sorting mesh elements and assigning them to different rendering layers (e.g., 'layout 0') to prevent objects from incorrectly drawing over each other.
The team is replacing many of the game's original actors with completely new models that are more detailed and visually distinct, such as the Goomba King, Spiked Goomba, and Bouncy Flower.

Kaze implemented a dynamic sun flare effect that rotates based on camera movement by manipulating the texture's UV coordinates, considering it a more performant solution than rotating the entire texture plane.
The current ROM size is around 63MB, approaching the self-imposed 64MB limit, which Kaze considers a good sign as they are on Course 14.

context_findings.summary: Kaze philosophically believes in adhering to the original 64MB cartridge size limit to maintain the spirit of N64 development, even though modern tools allow for much larger ROMs.
context_findings.quote: If you go over 64 MB, are you really still making an N64 game? I mean, you could argue you're making an N64 game because it runs on N64. But at the same time, it's kind of lame, right? It's like you're going beyond what they were able to do at the time. It just feels like cheating to me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze plans to create a video series analyzing his own level design, hoping that the process of articulating his choices and receiving feedback will lead to new insights for the project.
context_findings.quote: I was thinking of maybe making a series on my second channel, that's going to analyze why every individual course is worth playing... I think while doing this series, I might realize important things. Maybe people can give me important insights once they hear my thought processes.

context_findings.summary: Kaze jokes about branding himself as someone who 'hates video games' and is trying to create the 'first good one,' suggesting a potential frustration with the state of the industry that fuels his work.
context_findings.quote: Do you think branding my content as like, I hate video games, which is why I'm trying to make a good one, because I think all of the ones are bad. Would work out. Trying to make the first good video game.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states that his streams are a 'minimum effort' activity done primarily for his own enjoyment and to gather community feedback, not as a professional content creation career.
context_findings.quote: You need to realize my streams is like minimum effort. Really I just stream because I want to stream and because I like having people be able to give me feedback on this. I'm not trying to be like a professional streamer.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentioned that his modding work provides some income through YouTube and Patreon, but it is not even half of what his normal job makes.

biobak.summary: Biobak, as the 3D artist, provides the visual assets, but Kaze is responsible for the technical implementation and fixing rendering issues that arise because Biobak doesn't work directly with N64 limitations.
biobak.quote: This Biobak is not modeling directly on the N64, he's not gonna know what's going on. He doesn't know what's going to break and what won't.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a complete visual rework for Course 1, including new geometry and updated models for numerous actors like the Goomba King, Bouncy Flower, and rabbits.
Biobak requested specific visual features, such as an infinitely far background and a sun flare that rotates with the camera, which Kaze then implemented.
Biobak's updated Goomba model included a billboarded crown, but the implementation was incompatible with the game engine, forcing Kaze to rework it.
biobak.quote: I respect the attempt, Biobak, but I have to change it.

badub.summary: Badub has composed new music for the game, including a track for the grass area that has dynamic variations for different biomes.
badub.quote: What I forgot to mention is, this song has versions for every biome. Isn't that cool?

badub.summary: The game's audio engine will smoothly fade individual music channels in and out to transition between biome-specific versions of a song.

zeina.summary: Kaze jokingly blames Zeina (Lilaa) for his use of lowercase variables in his code.
zeina.quote: Lena is evil and she makes lowercase variables and that's why I'm forced into making lowercase variables too.

key_stories.title: Implementing the Dynamic Sun Flare
key_stories.summary: In response to a request from artist Biobak, Kaze implemented a dynamic sun flare effect. He chose a technically efficient method of manipulating UV coordinates, worked through several visual bugs, and ultimately created a polished effect that enhances the level's atmosphere.
key_stories.challenge: Biobak requested a dynamic sun flare that would spin as the player moves the camera, similar to a lens flare effect.
key_stories.process: Kaze decided against rotating the entire texture plane due to performance costs. Instead, he wrote a custom function to manipulate the texture's UV coordinates based on the camera's angle. He then debugged visual artifacts related to texture clamping and mirroring before fine-tuning the rotation speed and influence.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a visually impressive and performant sun flare that rotates based on camera yaw and pitch, which he was very pleased with.
key_stories.key_quote: Dealing with the UBs is easier.

key_stories.title: Fixing the Course 1 Rework
key_stories.summary: When importing the new art for Course 1 from Biobak, Kaze was faced with major graphical bugs due to the N64's rendering limitations. He systematically troubleshooted the draw order, re-organizing the level's geometry into proper rendering layers and verifying performance, ultimately achieving the intended visual upgrade.
key_stories.challenge: Integrating Biobak's major visual overhaul of Course 1, which was created in Blender without accounting for the N64's specific rendering pipeline.
key_stories.process: Kaze imported the new model and immediately encountered severe rendering artifacts. He systematically diagnosed the problem as an incorrect draw order. He then sorted mesh elements by material and distance and assigned them to different rendering layers to force the correct display. He concluded by running performance benchmarks to ensure the more complex geometry didn't harm the frame rate.
key_stories.outcome: After significant debugging, the new level geometry is implemented and running well, with Kaze calling it 'beautiful'. While some actor animation bugs remain, the core environment rework is a success.
key_stories.key_quote: Yeah, you can tell the drawing order here is pretty fucked.

key_stories.title: Importing and Debugging New Actor Models
key_stories.summary: The process of importing new character models from Biobak was complicated by technical incompatibilities with the game's animation system. Kaze had to diagnose issues with armatures and billboard implementations, performing initial fixes on-stream and scheduling the rest of the work for later.
key_stories.challenge: Importing Biobak's updated actor models, which had different armatures and setups than the existing in-game versions, causing broken animations.
key_stories.process: Kaze imported several updated models (Goomba King, Spiked Goomba, Bunny Goomba). He discovered that changes to the models' armatures and use of engine-incompatible features (like certain billboard setups) broke the existing animations. He performed initial fixes to get the models rendering but determined that fully correcting the animations would require more time.
key_stories.outcome: The new models are in the game, but their animations and behaviors are buggy. Kaze has identified the root causes and added the remaining fixes to his off-stream to-do list.
key_stories.key_quote: Okay, this behavior no longer matches his animation files, but that's fine.

open_questions.topic: Collaborative Workflow Between Kaze and Biobak
open_questions.context: Kaze states that artist Biobak doesn't model with N64 limitations in mind, leading to Kaze having to fix rendering issues upon import. This implies a specific, potentially challenging, collaborative workflow.
questions: Can you walk me through the typical workflow with Biobak, from concept to final in-game asset?
How do you communicate the N64's technical limitations to him? Do you have a set of guidelines?
Can you give an example of a time a model was particularly difficult to implement and how you two worked through it?

open_questions.context: Kaze expressed a strong philosophical stance against exceeding the 64MB ROM size of original N64 cartridges, calling it 'cheating'.
questions: Why is the 64MB limit so important to you personally? What does 'respecting the hardware' mean in the context of a modern ROM hack?
Does this self-imposed limitation force creative decisions you wouldn't otherwise make? Can you give an example?
How does the rest of the team feel about this limitation? Has it ever been a point of contention?

open_questions.context: Kaze explained the technical implementation of Mario's 'jiggle physics' nose in great detail, revealing it's a custom physics system, not a simple animation.
questions: What was the inspiration for adding custom physics to Mario's nose? Why invest time in such a small detail?
You mentioned it's 'hyper-optimized'. What was the process of optimizing that code?
Are there other small, 'unnecessary' details like this in the game that you're particularly proud of?

open_questions.context: Kaze played new music from Badub and mentioned it has dynamic versions for different biomes that will transition smoothly by fading channels in and out.
questions: How does the collaboration with Badub work? Do you provide a level and ask for music, or is it more iterative?
Can you explain the technical side of the dynamic music system? How does the game know when to transition between the different versions of a track?
How do you and Badub decide on the musical identity for a course or biome?

open_questions.context: While implementing the new Goomba King model, Kaze mentioned, 'We're gonna change the Goombas fight a little bit though. So don't worry if you think it sucks right now.'
questions: What are the planned changes for the Goomba King boss fight?
What is the design philosophy behind this change? What problem are you trying to solve with the current fight?
How do you approach redesigning existing encounters? What's the process?
